goal.ch:
An introduction to the principles of active tectonic geology from Miocene till present. Emphasis on plate tectonics, fault mechanics, basic seismology, tectonic geomorphology (as landform-related subsurface processes), Quaternary dating techniques, earthquake geology, seismic hazard analysis, aerial photography mapping, and field mapping. Two units: class and fieldwork (if possible).
The course is designed for both geology graduate and undergraduate students (4th). Prerequisites for the course are physical geology, structural geology, basics of petrology, sedimentology. The goal of the course is to acquaint students with the disciplines that are the foundation of tectonic geology.  Students who complete the course should gain basic knowledge and skills useful for preparing themselves for neotectonic research and the geotechnical/consulting industry.

outline.ch:
Week 1 – Introduction, assignment of tasks, etc.
Week 2 – Neotectonic framework of Taiwan. The velocity field in southern Taiwan based on geodesy.
Week 3 –Stress interaction of fault geometries.
Week 4 –The fault in a seismogenic crust, fault creep, heat flow, and the generation of earthquakes. Models of fault zone architecture, damage zones, cataclasites, mylonites, psuedotachylites
Week 5 – Pulverized rock, fracturing, other damage.
Week 6 – Dating of offset geomorphic features, determination of slip rates. Fault slip rates and loading over time.
Week 7 – Fault segmentation and “characteristic” earthquakes, models of earthquake recurrence. Morphologic mapping of slip events on faults.
Week 8 – Landforms related to subsurface deformation. Mapping, UAV techniques.
Week 9 – Trenching analysis of faults and interpretation of earthquakes (Paleoseismology)
3-dimensional trenching and resolution of displacement.
Week 10 – Crustal Shortening: Reverse faults, folding and uplift.
Week 11 – Marine terraces, sea level history and uplift.
Week 12 – Extensional Faulting: Normal fault paleoseismology.
Week 13 – Scarp morphology and dating using diffusion modelling.
Week 14 – The Shanchiao fault as a laboratory possibly Quaternary dating technique(s).
Week 15 – UAV-acquired landforms and interpretation- projects
Week 16 – Work on final projects
Week 17-?  – final weeks for presentation and final exam
